title: Yascha Mounk
text:
Yascha Mounk (born 10 June 1982) is a <a href="German%20Americans">German-American</a> <a href="Political%20science">political scientist</a>. He is currently Associate Professor of Practice at <a href="Paul%20H.%20Nitze%20School%20of%20Advanced%20International%20Studies">Johns Hopkins University's School of Advanced International Studies</a> in Washington D.C.
Early life.
Mounk was born and raised in <a href="Munich">Munich</a>. His mother was <a href="Jewish">Jewish</a> and a <a href="socialist">socialist</a> and was forced to leave <a href="Poland">Poland</a> in 1969 due to antisemitism. He wrote that much of his mother's side of the family was killed in <a href="the%20Holocaust">the Holocaust</a>. He has said he felt like a stranger in Germany and though <a href="German%20language">German</a> is his native language, he never felt accepted as a "true German" by his peers. Mounk received a <a href="Bachelor%20of%20Arts">BA degree</a> in history from <a href="Trinity%20College%2C%20Cambridge">Trinity College</a> (<a href="University%20of%20Cambridge">Cambridge</a>). He then received a <a href="Doctor%20of%20Philosophy">PhD</a> from <a href="Harvard%20University">Harvard University</a> in the <a href="United%20States">United States</a>. He remained in the U.S. as a lecturer on government and was named a senior fellow in the Political Reform Program at the think tank <a href="New%20America%20%28organization%29">New America</a>. Mounk became an American citizen in 2017.
Career.
He was executive director of the Renewing the Centre team at the <a href="Tony%20Blair%20Institute%20for%20Global%20Change">Tony Blair Institute for Global Change</a>. As a <a href="Freelancer">freelance journalist</a> he has written for the "<a href="New%20York%20Times">New York Times</a>", "<a href="The%20Wall%20Street%20Journal">The Wall Street Journal</a>", "<a href="Foreign%20Affairs">Foreign Affairs</a>", "<a href="The%20Atlantic">The Atlantic</a>" and "<a href="Slate%20%28magazine%29">Slate</a>". He runs a <a href="podcast">podcast</a> called "The Good Fight". His dissertation on the role of personal responsibility in contemporary politics and philosophy has been published by <a href="Harvard%20University%20Press">Harvard University Press</a>.
In July 2020, he founded "<a href="Persuasion%20%28online%20magazine%29">Persuasion</a>", an online magazine devoted to defending the values of free societies.
Political views.
Mounk joined the <a href="Social%20Democratic%20Party%20of%20Germany">Social Democratic Party of Germany</a> (SPD) as a teenager. In 2015 he resigned from the party, doing so by publishing an open letter to then-chairman <a href="Sigmar%20Gabriel">Sigmar Gabriel</a>. He cited the lack of helpfulness of German institutions to refugees, the passive attitude of SPD leaders and other parts of the party during the <a href="Annexation%20of%20Crimea%20by%20the%20Russian%20Federation">Crimea crisis</a> in 2014, and the SPD's policy on Greece, which he called a "betrayal of the social democratic dream of a united Europe".
In a February 2018 interview that was published in "<a href="S%C3%BCddeutsche%20Zeitung">Süddeutsche Zeitung</a>", Mounk stated that he had changed his position on <a href="nationalism">nationalism</a>. He initially considered it a relic of the past that must be overcome, but he now advocates an "inclusive nationalism" to head off the threat of aggressive nationalism. On the German television newscast "<a href="Tagesthemen">Tagesthemen</a>", he stated that Germany is on a "historically unique experiment, namely to transform a <a href="Monoethnicity">mono-ethnic</a> and <a href="Monoculturalism">monocultural</a> democracy into a <a href="multi-ethnic">multi-ethnic</a> one." In the <a href="Media%20of%20Israel">Israeli newspaper</a> "<a href="Haaretz">Haaretz</a>", Mounk advised the "<a href="liberalism">liberal</a> camp" to adopt this inclusive nationalism, to foster a multi-ethnic and democratic society. "The key... is the adoption of the populist demand that people and nations should again feel they have control of their lives or their destiny."
